Entry Question: We’re experimenting with a unified lead capture experience
Response:
What is it?

We’re experimenting with combining CTAs, forms, and lead flows into one unified “Lead Capture” dashboard.

Why does it matter?

HubSpot provides you with a full suite of lead capture tools to help you convert visitors to your site into leads for your marketing and sales team to nurture into customers. With CTAs, forms, and lead flows, it can often be a challenge for users to get started and assimilated to the tools available to them. A major reason for this was that once you’ve implemented each lead capture tool, the reporting and analytics experience for each was different, leading to a confusing experience.

With this in mind, we’re experimenting with unifying the three tools into one dashboard to provide you with a more consistent experience when creating and analyzing your conversion points in HubSpot. Ideally, this will make it easier for our customers to fully understand the conversion tools available to them within HubSpot, make a smarter choice for which tool to use based on their specific needs, and adopt new tools.

How does it work?

Within the main navigation, clicking on either CTAs, forms, or lead flows will bring you to a dashboard that includes all three tools.

Clicking on an individual CTA, form, or lead flow, you’ll be presented with a similar details screen for each, giving you consistent data and conversion metrics across all lead capture assets.

Free users who are part of this experiment will see a PQL within the CTAs tool.

Who gets it?

We’ll be rolling this out into a small experimental beta next week to collect feedback. The beta will be given to half of all new free CRM accounts to see if the dashboard increases cross adoption to other lead capture tools. At this time, we don’t have more information about when this will be more broadly available.

What language is it in?

All languages supported by HubSpot

Entry Question: Analyze Tab Reports are Moving to the Reports Library

Entry Question: Introducing the new Report Builder (Including Cross-Object Reporting)

Entry Question: Change Filters for Dashboard Emails
Response:
What is it?

Scheduled dashboard emails have always been a great way for users to show off progress and share metrics with their team. Up until now, scheduled emails have included a snapshot of the reports using the dashboard’s saved filters.

 

With today’s change, users can now choose how they want the reports on the dashboard to be filtered for each individual email - whether it’s a recurring share or a one-off send.

I don’t get it. Can you give me an example or two?

Sure.

 

Let’s say you set up a custom lead gen dashboard for your marketing team, and you want to email it to them at three frequencies: daily (with the previous day’s metrics), monthly (with the previous month’s waterfall), and quarterly. Previously, you would’ve had to set up three dashboards in order to set up those three emails — even though they include all the same data. Now, set up one dashboard, and update the filter for each email send.

 

Or perhaps you set up a dashboard for your sales performance, and you’d like to set up recurring emails to two different teams that reflect their data (or two pipelines, perhaps). Previously, you would’ve had to set up two dashboards in order to set up those two emails — even though they all include the same data. Now, set up one dashboard, and update the filter for each email send.

 

How does it work?

From any report dashboard, click “Share” in the top right corner. Select either “Email Now” or “Create a recurring email” to schedule your dashboard send.

 

At the bottom, you’ll see a new section, “Dashboard context,” with two options: “send dashboard without filters” and “send dashboard with filters.”

 

If you choose “send dashboard without filters,” it’ll simply send using the dashboard’s saved filters.

 

If you’d prefer to send with a different set of filters (i.e. a different team, pipeline, or owner), choose “send dashboard with filters” and configure your desired filters, then schedule the email.

 

 

Who gets it?

All HubSpot customers. It's live now --- no need for "ungating."

Entry Question: A New Web Analytics Dashboard
Response:
What is it

A new dashboard that shows brings the most pivotal top-of-funnel metrics into HubSpot: bounce rate, device and location metrics, new vs. returning sessions, and more.

Why it matters

Up until now, customers have been able to dig into their Sources and Page Performance reports for high-level data on how well their website attracts and engages visitors. These reports do a good job at answering questions like:

  • How many site visits am I getting over time?
  • Which channels (sources) are bringing the most traffic & converting that traffic to leads and customers?
  • How many keywords are my pages ranking for?
  • Are visitors clicking on my calls to action?

In conversations with customers, we lean into the idea that HubSpot provides marketing analytics. And customers love those marketing analytics.

But, as is often the case, our customers are always itching for more. In this case, they're seeking out web analytics — things like bounce rate, device type, etc.

In the past, customers have turned to other tools for in-depth web analytics, namely Google Analytics. With the new web analytics dashboard, we're expanding the horizons of what's available to customers right inside HubSpot stack.

The goal here is to deliver deeper insights to our customers on how visitors are finding and engaging with their content — to not only put marketing analytics and web analytics under the same roof, but to find new ways to connect the two, in order to provide even greater value to customers.

 

How it works

Navigate to your Marketing Dashboard and use the Dashboards dropdown to select Web Analytics Dashboard.

You’ll be greeted by your brand new Web Analytics dashboard:

To start, note that your new dashboard has all the features you’re used to in HubSpot dashboards.

  • Drag and drop reports with the click of a mouse.
  • Download a PDF or PPT version of the dashboard using the “Export” button.
  • Set up a recurring email of the dashboard (e.g. before your Monday morning marketing meeting) using “Share” in the upper-right corner.
  • You can add any report from your other dashboards to the web analytics dashboard, and any web analytics report to one of your other dashboards.

Here’s a quick rundown of the reports you’ll see on the dashboard:

  • Sessions. The number of sessions over time, split out by new vs. returning session.
  • Traffic Metrics. Total sessions, % new sessions, and % mobile sessions during your selected timeframe.
  • Engagement Metrics. Your website’s bounce rate, average time on site, and pages per session.
  • Session Sources. Sessions over time, split out by original source (organic, paid, etc.).
  • Session Engagement Rates by Source. Bounce rate, average time on site, and pages per session, broken down by original source.
  • New Visitor Sessions by Source. Sessions from new visitors, broken down by original source.
  • Average Pages per Session by Source. How many pages visitors viewed in an average session, split out by original source.
  • Average Session Length by Source. Number of minutes/seconds spent on your website per session, broken down by original source.
  • Bounce Rate by Source. Bounce rate --- number of sessions with only one page view divided by total number of sessions --- by original source.
  • Sessions by Device Type. The number of sessions broken by mobile vs. desktop.
  • Device Type Breakdown. Mobile vs. desktop, in pie chart form.
  • Session Country. The countries where your sessions originated, identified by IP address. Any of these reports can be added to your other dashboards in HubSpot. Want a snapshot of your device type metrics on your primary marketing dashboard? Add it in two clicks using “Add Report” in the upper-right corner.

Who gets it? All Basic, Professional, and Enterprise HubSpot Marketing Portals.

FAQ

There are new metrics I haven't seen in HubSpot before - what do these mean?

  • Sessions - A session is a series of analytics activities taken by a visitor to your website. Activities can include page views, CTA clicks, events, etc. A session expires after 30 minute of inactivity. For specific examples of a session, read through this Wiki post.
  • Bounce Rate - # of sessions with exactly 1 analytics event / total sessions  

What is a Session and how is it different from a Visit?

A “session” and a “visit” are two different ways to categorize groups of interactions a visitor has on your website. Specifically, a visit is counted when a visitor arrives on your website from a page outside your website. A session, however, is a more comprehensive way of grouping interactions. Sessions take into account interactions other than page views, such as events and CTA clicks. Sessions also have time-based expirations, whereas a visit does not. Yearning for specific examples of sessions vs. visits? Read through this Wiki post.

Via the in-app tally widget.

  1. We’ve pushed call dispositions live to all HubSpot Sales users. You can now track the outcome of every call made via HubSpot Sales.
  2. We’ve introduced new sales content report templates to all HubSpot Sales Professional users. Seven new canned reports for HubSpot dashboards that provide analytics on calls, meetings, and sequences.

Today’s updates enable you to get a clearer view of your reps’ productivity. Implement a more consistent call-logging process with call dispositions, and zero-in on specific engagement data to identify the parts of your reps’ process that need the most work using the new reporting functionality.

Call Dispositions

Make a call from any record in HubSpot CRM by using the communicator at the top of the screen. Once a call is completed, simply select the outcome of the call from the dropdown menu and select ‘Save call’.  A recording of that call, along with its outcome, will be saved to the contact’s timeline.

Sales content report templates

Navigate to your Sales Dashboard (or any of your other dashboards, if you have the Reporting Add-on). Click “Add Report.”

On the subsequent page, within the widget library, you’ll see seven new canned reports available:

  • Total Calls. How many calls your team is making each month.
  • Calls Made by Reps. A stackranking of your reps by # of calls made.
  • Average Call Duration. Find out who is spending the most time talking to their prospects.
  • Total Meetings Booked. Shows how many total meetings your team has booked in the selected timeframe.
  • Meetings Booked by Rep. Break down the meetings booked chart by rep.
  • Call Outcomes. Which reps actually connect with their prospects? Which are stuck leaving voicemails most often?
  • Sequence Performance. Hone in on which sequences are the most effective. This report shows enrollment, replies, and reply rate for your best-performing sequences.

See all these reports in action on this demo dashboard.

Build a custom report in the Reporting Add-on by navigating to any dashboard, clicking "Add Report," and clicking "Create Custom Widget."

Once in the custom builder, choose "Engagements" as your type. By default, you'll see every engagement logged by any of your reps. To filter your report, use the Engagement Type and Engagement Owners selectors in the left-hand sidebar. For example, if you only wanted to see the calls and meetings booked by Taylor Swift or Curious George, you'd set up your filters like this:

Example reports (If you're confused by the custom report builder, read this part...)

  • Calls/Meetings/Tasks by a specific set of reps, aggregated
  • Calls/Meetings over time, by type (for a specific set of reps)

Entry Question: What are the limits of the reporting add-on?
Response:
• Cross object reporting. Right now, you can create a report with fields on a single object. E.g. Run a report on contacts created over time, by persona. Persona is a property on the contact object, so this report works. What we can't do today: run reports with fields on two different objects at once. E.g. a report on all the deals whose companies have fewer than 200 employees, or a report of deals broken down by the original source of their primary contact. We're planning to address this in the near future, but for now, it's a gap in the functionality.
  • Campaign reporting. It's not possible to run a custom report on all the contacts associated with a campaign. It's also not possible to run a report comparing campaigns to each other in custom ways. Also something we're planning to address, but for now, not a strength.
  • Engagement reporting. There are several canned widgets on email, call, and meeting volume, but there's very little customization. Entry Question: Closed-loop revenue reporting for abandoned cart emails
Response:
What is it

The ability to tie your abandoned cart emails to closed deals and revenue.

Why it matters

Sending emails is great. But if they’re not actually driving revenue, what’s the point? For a marketer, it’s critical that you connect your efforts to the bottom line, both to show your value to your company, and to ensure you’re focusing on the most impactful efforts in the future. With that in mind, we’re breaking down the wall between marketing emails and deals in HubSpot for the first time.

How it works

Customers will now see a new info panel a new set of stats on the post-send email screen:

Below that, they’ll get a new roll-up of clicked product links in the “Top Clicked Links” panel:

And deals closed over time included within the “Engagement over time” report:

Beyond this, they also get an additional breakdown of recipients who closed a deal, and what they ordered (+ revenue) on the Recipients tab of this screen:

FAQ’s

  • What’s the difference between Orders and Deals?

    • No difference, they’re the same thing. In the context of the ecommerce integration the most common way to refer to a closed deal is an order which is what we’re following here for the moment.

  • What does “Influenced” in Influenced Revenue mean?

    • We calculate influenced as meaning any deal that was closed after engagement on this email.

  • What if two contacts from the same company clicked the email, but only one deal was closed?

    • The revenue is deduplicated by deal, so while both contacts would show up in the Recipients tab as having closed a deal/placed an order, we would only count the revenue once so the number will not be inflated.

Who gets it

This feature is now available on all abandoned cart emails built within the ecommerce integration in HubSpot.

What’s next?

To start, we’re introducing revenue reporting to abandoned cart emails associated with our ecommerce integration, as they’re the most cleanly connected to revenue. Over time, we’ll be working to bring revenue to all marketing emails. In addition, we’re looking at other ways to connect Email to other tools in HubSpot, including closed-loop Meeting reporting (which emails result in the most meetings booked) and closed-loop Survey reporting (which emails result in the most surveys submitted). Going even further, we’ll find ways to expand these concepts beyond email, allowing you to identify the impact other marketing assets like social/forms/CTAs. What it is

A new report for comparing high-level campaign analytics: traffic generated, contacts created and influenced, and deals/revenue created and influenced.

 

Why it matters

(internal background)

A few years back, we built a tool for customers to be able to connect and measure every aspect of a marketing initiative in one place: campaigns.

Campaigns has proven to be excellent at the first part of that equation: connecting assets. A customer can tag a set of assets (blog post, landing page, etc.) with a certain campaign, then see all those pieces in one place within the campaigns tool. Think: a slightly fancier foldering system.

The bitter truth: in the second part of that equation, we’ve fallen woefully short. We asked a set of HubSpot customers specifically how they measure their campaigns, and we got a whole lot of this:

 

“Omg I don’t know :)”

“We don’t.”

“We need help.”

“??”

“n/a”

“We can’t/don’t. Reporting is a HUGE issue for us.”

“It’s a pain and thus not done.”

Our customers deserve a better way to report on their campaigns. So we built them one.

 

(external messaging - the “story”)

It’s the end of the month. Your company is ecstatic, because the revenue goal was hit. But --- like usual --- the sales team is getting the high-fives, the end-of-month beers, and the bonuses. Nobody ever gives marketing the applause when things go well, but they're fast to dole out the blame when things don't. Why does that always happen?

Your work makes a huge impact on the growth of the business. But the harsh reality is this: making an impact is meaningless if it can’t be measured. A slide with traffic metrics from your web analytics tool, another with lead gen numbers from your forms or marketing automation tool, and a third with revenue data from your CRM aren't enough. Entry Question: How does HubSpot categorize Visits, Contacts, and Customers in the Sources Report?
Response:
HubSpot analyzes each visit to your website and applies a series of rules to determine the marketing source of the visit. Contacts and Customers in the Sources report are categorized by the date of their first conversion, based on the source of their first known visit.

There are 8 potential categories used by the Sources Report (more specific rules can be found below):

  • Organic Search: Non-paid visits from recognized search engines, like Google, Bing, Yahoo, etc.
  • Referrals: Visits from links clicked on other websites.
  • Social Media: Visits from links clicked on social media sites, like Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, etc.
  • Email Marketing: Visits from tracking links in your emails. These links are automatically added to the emails you send from HubSpot. They can also be manually added using tracking URLs for external email systems.
  • Paid Search: Visits from paid search ads that are either automatically identified by HubSpot or set by tracking URLs.
  • Paid Social: Visits from a paid social campaign from either the HubSpot Ads Add-on or a paid social campaign set by tracking URLs.
  • Direct Traffic: Visits to your website with no referring source or tracking URL; usually visitors who type your website URL directly into their browser.
  • Other Campaigns: Visits from campaigns that are being monitored with specific tracking URL parameters other than those used for Social Media, Email, or Paid Search.
  • Offline Sources: This category does not apply to visits, but contacts and customers who originated outside of your website (manual, imported, API). This will also appear as the source for contacts created by a form submission who are filtered from analytics by IP address. In the Sources Report, Offline Sources is hidden by default.

Source: Academy

Entry Question: When looking at Paid Traffic via Sources why are the bulk of the keywords filed under "Content Network (Adsense or Other)"? How can he get better data on these words?
Response:
• Auto-tagged PPC: HubSpot is able to detect that the visit was from Paid Search, but was not provided with a parameter for the campaign name.
    • If you are using Google Adwords and have auto-tagging enabled, then HubSpot is not able to determine a value for the campaign from Google's auto-tagged URL. To separate your paid search visits by campaign when using Adwords, click here to learn more.
  • Content network (Adsense or other): Visit came from a content network or HubSpot was not provided with the paid ad's search term parameter for the visit.
    • This is common when using Adsense, or any type of shared content network, that does not pass the search term in the ad's URL.
    • If you created a tracking URL in HubSpot to bucket visits under Paid Search, the search term may also not be included in the ad's URL.
  • Unknown Keywords SSL: HubSpot recognizes that a search term parameter was contained in the URL, but it was encrypted by the provider before the visit was recorded.
    • Google now encrypts most visits from their search engine and ads which means that the search term parameter is no longer provided to analytics tools, such as HubSpot.

Entry Question: Can I Filter Out Specific Referring Domains from HubSpot Reports
Response:
What is it?

The ability to block specific referring domains from your website analytics in HubSpot.

Why it matters?

Not all traffic to your website is good traffic. Metrics may be skewed by data from your own IP addresses (your own employees visiting your website), or from spam (bots or other “fake” traffic). Previously, you could filter traffic from certain IP addresses.

Today’s change enables you to get even more precise with your filtering by removing referral traffic from specific domains of your choosing, ensuring that pesky bots don’t dilute your analytics.

How it works

Navigate to Reports > Reports Settings and find the section for “Exclude traffic from these referrers.” Add any domain URLs that you'd like to block from your analytics. This will filter future referral traffic from reports like Sources, the Marketing Dashboard, and Page Performance, etc.


Note: if “example.com” is added, traffic from http://example.com and any subdomain (e.g. blog.example.com) will be filtered out. If “blog.example.com” is added, only the “blog” subdomain is filtered out of analytics.

Entry Question: Bot Filter Checkbox in Reports Settings
Response:
What is it?

A new setting that lets you block a set of known bots from your website analytics in HubSpot.

 

Why it matters?

Not all traffic to your website is good traffic. Metrics may be skewed by data from your own IP addresses (your own employees visiting your website), phony referral sources, and spam (bots or other “fake” traffic). When your data is diluted, it’s harder to draw meaningful conclusions and to trust your metrics over time.

Previously, you could filter traffic from certain IP addresses out of your HubSpot data. Then, with an update last month, you can now remove referral traffic from specific domains of your choosing.

With today’s change, get even more precise with your filtering by removing traffic from specific known bots, so that you can focus your analysis on the traffic that will actually drive your business forward.

How it works

Navigate to Reports > Reports Settings and find the checkbox for “Bot filtering”.

Checking the box will prevent future traffic from known bots (e.g. specific AWS IPs) from appearing in reports like Sources, the Marketing Dashboard, and Page Performance, etc.

Technical note: This new setting is in addition to the filtering that we already do. Before today’s change, HubSpot automatically filtered out traffic that identified itself as a bot (e.g. search engine crawlers that say that they’re a bot in their user agent). The new setting aims to add more granularity by filtering IP addresses that don’t necessarily identify themselves as bots, but are are known as such.

Who gets it?

All users of the Marketing product (Basic, Pro, Enterprise) will be able to use this setting in Reports Settings.

 

Source: Product Notifications

Entry Question: Analytics Tracking for Single-Page Applications
Response:
What is it:

New functions in the HubSpot tracking code that let customers track single-page application websites in HubSpot Marketing’s analytics tools.

Why it matters:

Customers who host their websites outside the HubSpot COS sometimes use JavaScript to power navigation, instead of creating separate pages. This setup is called a single-page app (or SPA for short).

With this configuration, all necessary code – HTML, JavaScript, and CSS – is retrieved with a single page load. The page does not reload at any point in the process. A classic example is Gmail: when you click on a message in your inbox, the browser doesn’t refresh the web page, but JavaScript code hides the inbox and brings the message body onto the screen.

Previously, websites built with SPA technology couldn’t be tracked in HubSpot Marketing because of their unique setup. This significantly limited the usefulness of HubSpot reports for those customers.

With today’s change, customers can track SPA websites fully in HubSpot Marketing, with very little additional effort.

How it works:

Customers who have built single-page applications can now add additional JavaScript to their websites to use new functions in the HubSpot tracking code. The new functions let the customer signal to HubSpot’s back-end systems that a page has changed, so that session interactions can be logged accurately on the contact timeline and in HubSpot reports.

The technical details of the changes have been posted to our public developer documents.

Who gets it: All HubSpot Marketing Basic, Pro, and Enterprise customers.

Entry Question: How do I track multiple domains with HubSpot?
Response:
You can set up cross-domain tracking to ensure that the same tracking cookie is used across your tracked domains. Cross-domain tracking allows HubSpot to merge the visitor profiles of one person as they travel across your multiple domains into a single contact profile.

 This merging can take place when one of two things happens:

  1. A visitor fills out more than one form with the same email address across multiple domains on which you have your HubSpot tracking code installed.
  2. A visitor clicks on a link that takes them between two different domains, each of which have your HubSpot tracking code installed on them. HubSpot attaches parameters to your links from one domain to another (__hsfp, __hssc, and __hstc) to track visitors as they travel between domains. You must have automatic cross-domain link tracking enabled in your reports settings for this to work.

Please note: this is only necessary to track traffic between distinct domains (e.g. thisdomain.com and anotherdomain.com). This requirement is a result of a privacy limitation of cookies, where cookies are set at the domain level and cannot be carried from one domain to the next. Traffic between subdomains (e.g. www.hubspot.com to blog.hubspot.com) is automatically tracked using cookies. 

*This has been removed from the article in english but should be added again*

  1. Marketing Dashboard & Traffic Analytics will be merged
  2. Forms can be embedded on any page on any domain but all contacts will be added to the same database.
